source.name: Manchester City Council
source.notes: Based on official Manchester City Council bin guidelines. Multi-bin system: blue (paper/card), brown (mixed recycling), green (food/garden), grey (general waste). Tetra Paks go in blue bin.

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place in blue bin (paper and card)
notes: Blue bin is for paper and card ONLY
commonMistakes: Don't put in the brown bin — brown is for plastics, cans, and glass
Don't include if wet or heavily soiled

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Glossy paper is fine in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put the plastic wrapper in the blue bin — put it in the grey bin

materials.name: Envelopes
notes: Windowed envelopes are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include padded or bubble-lined envelopes — those go in grey bin

materials.name: Junk mail and leaflets
notes: Includes glossy and non-glossy leaflets
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily laminated

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Place in blue bin or beside it if too large
notes: Large boxes can be left next to the blue bin on collection day
commonMistakes: Don't include boxes soiled with food or grease
Don't leave packing materials inside

materials.name: Cereal boxes
instructions: Remove the inner plastic bag (grey bin)
notes: The inner plastic liner goes in the grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag

materials.name: Cardboard egg trays
notes: Cardboard egg trays only — not plastic or polystyrene
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic or polystyrene egg boxes — those go in grey bin

materials.name: Toilet and kitchen roll tubes
instructions: Flatten and place in blue bin
notes: Cardboard tubes are easily recycled
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels — those go in green bin or grey bin

materials.name: Food and drink cartons (Tetra Paks)
instructions: Place in blue bin (paper and card)
notes: In Manchester, Tetra Paks go in the BLUE bin with paper and card
This is different from many other councils
commonMistakes: Don't put in the brown bin — they go in the blue bin in Manchester

materials.name: Greeting cards
notes: Cards with glitter must have glittery parts removed or go in grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't include glittery cards without removing glitter
Don't include musical cards with batteries

materials.name: Clean cardboard takeaway boxes
instructions: Only if clean and not grease-soaked
notes: Must be clean — greasy boxes go in the grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't include greasy or food-soiled boxes — those go in grey bin

materials.name: Writing and printing paper
notes: Staples are fine — removed during processing
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in the blue bin — use green bin or grey bin

materials.name: Wrapping paper (non-metallic)
instructions: Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it can be recycled
notes: Foil or glittery wrapping paper goes in the grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't include metallic or glittery wrapping paper

materials.name: Phone books and directories
notes: Can go in whole

materials.name: Paper bags
notes: Remove any plastic handles
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated paper bags

materials.name: Shoeboxes
instructions: Flatten and place in blue bin
notes: Remove any tissue paper or plastic inserts
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic or foam inserts

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: Brown bin is for plastics, cans, and glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin — that's paper/card only

materials.name: Plastic pots, tubs, and trays
notes: Most plastic pots, tubs, and trays accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene trays
Don't include black plastic trays

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: All colours of glass accepted in the brown bin
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass, window glass, or drinking glasses

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: Remove metal lids (recycle lids in brown bin too)
notes: All colours of glass jars accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include Pyrex or ceramics

materials.name: Aluminium cans
notes: Aluminium is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Steel tins and cans
notes: Labels can be left on
commonMistakes: Don't include paint tins

materials.name: Aluminium foil
notes: Manchester accepts foil in the brown bin — scrunch it into a ball so it doesn't blow away
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily food-soiled foil

materials.name: Aerosol cans
notes: Manchester accepts aerosols in the brown bin
commonMistakes: Don't include cans that still have contents
Don't puncture aerosols

materials.name: Plastic milk bottles
notes: One of the most commonly recycled items
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin — brown bin only

materials.name: Cleaning product bottles
notes: Trigger sprays can be left on
commonMistakes: Don't include partly full bottles

materials.name: Yoghurt pots
notes: Foil lids can also go in the brown bin
commonMistakes: Don't leave food residue

materials.name: Margarine and spread tubs
notes: Plastic tubs from spreads are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't leave residue

materials.name: Drink cans
notes: Both aluminium and steel drink cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Biscuit and sweet tins
notes: Metal tins are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic tray inserts

materials.name: Food tins
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include paint or chemical tins

materials.name: Plastic food containers
notes: Rigid plastic food containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene containers

materials.name: Foil trays
notes: Must be clean — greasy foil trays go in the grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily soiled with food

materials.name: Food scraps and leftovers
instructions: Place in green bin (food and garden waste)
notes: All cooked and uncooked food accepted
Green bin is collected fortnightly in most areas
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bins

materials.name: Tea bags
notes: Accepted in Manchester's green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bins

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
notes: Paper filters can go in too
commonMistakes: Don't include coffee pods

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable peelings
notes: All fruit and veg waste accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bins

materials.name: Eggshells
notes: Crush to save space

materials.name: Grass cuttings
notes: Green bin accepts both food and garden waste
commonMistakes: Don't include soil or stones

materials.name: Hedge trimmings and prunings
instructions: Cut to fit in green bin
notes: Woody branches should be cut into small pieces
commonMistakes: Don't include large branches that don't fit

materials.name: Dead flowers and plants
notes: Remove any pots, wire, or plastic before putting in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic pots or oasis foam

materials.name: Leaves
notes: Great for composting

materials.name: Stale bread and pastries
notes: All bakery products accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include packaging

materials.name: Meat, fish, and bones
notes: Both raw and cooked accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bins

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Small amounts of dairy are fine
commonMistakes: Don't pour liquids directly in

materials.name: Plastic bags and wrappers
notes: Some supermarkets have soft plastic collection points
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue or brown bin

materials.name: Polystyrene and styrofoam
notes: Not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in any recycling bin

materials.name: Nappies and sanitary products
notes: Never place in recycling or green bins
commonMistakes: Don't put in any recycling bin or the green bin

materials.name: Cling film and plastic wrap
notes: Not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in any recycling bin

materials.name: Crisp packets and sweet wrappers
notes: Made of mixed materials — not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in any recycling bin — they look metallic but aren't aluminium

materials.name: Bubble wrap
instructions: Or take to supermarket soft plastics point
notes: Not accepted in kerbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the brown or blue bin

materials.name: Broken crockery and ceramics
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the brown bin with glass

materials.name: Drinking glasses and Pyrex
notes: Different melting point to bottle glass — contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the brown bin

materials.name: Wet wipes
notes: Most wet wipes contain plastic
commonMistakes: Don't flush — they cause sewer blockages

materials.name: Tissues and paper towels
notes: Too degraded and contaminated to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Food-soiled packaging
notes: Grease contaminates paper and card recycling
Tear off clean parts and recycle those in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue bin

materials.name: Cotton wool and cotton buds
notes: Not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't flush cotton buds

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Place in grey bin or take to HWRC if large
notes: Different composition to bottle glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the brown bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a battery collection point at supermarkets or council buildings
Never put in any household bin
notes: Batteries cause fires in bin lorries
commonMistakes: Never put in household bins — fire risk

materials.name: Electronics and electricals
instructions: Take to household waste recycling centre (HWRC)
notes: Under WEEE regulations, retailers must accept old items
commonMistakes: Don't put in any household bin

materials.name: Paint and varnish
instructions: Take to household waste recycling centre (HWRC)
notes: Never pour down drains
commonMistakes: Don't put in any bin
Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to HWRC
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or LED bulbs in any bin
Don't put in the brown bin with glass

materials.name: Textiles and clothes
instructions: Donate to charity shops if in good condition
Use textile banks or take to HWRC
notes: Even damaged textiles can be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in any bin — donate or use textile banks
Don't throw good clothes in the grey bin

recycle: Blue bin: newspapers, magazines, cardboard, envelopes, junk mail, cereal boxes, Tetra Paks, greeting cards
Brown bin: plastic bottles/pots/tubs/trays, glass bottles/jars, aluminium and steel cans/tins, foil, aerosols
Paper and card ONLY in the blue bin — everything else recycled in the brown bin
compost: Green bin: all food waste (cooked and uncooked)
Green bin: garden waste (grass, hedge trimmings, leaves, flowers)
trash: Grey bin: plastic bags, wrappers, cling film
Grey bin: polystyrene, crisp packets, bubble wrap
Grey bin: nappies, wet wipes, tissues
Grey bin: broken crockery, drinking glasses, mirrors

recycle: Plastic bags, wrappers, cling film — jam sorting machinery
Textiles and clothes — use charity shops or textile banks
Food waste — use the green bin

tips: Manchester uses a FOUR bin system: blue (paper/card), brown (mixed recycling), green (food/garden), grey (general waste)
Tetra Paks go in the BLUE bin in Manchester — not the brown bin
Flatten cardboard to save space in the blue bin
Rinse containers before putting in the brown bin
Scrunch foil into a ball before putting in the brown bin
Never bag your recycling — empty items loose into the bin
Check your collection schedule at manchester.gov.uk
Batteries and vapes cause fires — take to collection points

locations.name: Longley Lane Household Waste Recycling Centre
Reliance Street Household Waste Recycling Centre
locations.address: Reliance Street, Newton Heath, Manchester M40 3EJ
